utterances: Haas suspects that what changed was El Nino, the cycle of warm ocean water and torrential rains that regularly descends on western South America.
Some shift in the coupling of the atmosphere and the Pacific Ocean made El Ninos more frequent.
Haas doesn't know why it happened, but he believes more frequent El Ninos had a drastic effect on coastal life.
They were pushing out the cold-water fish and bringing in warm-water fish.
They kill off local clams and mussels.
The fishing got bad, the weather unpredictable.
So people moved inland, to the desert valleys.
It was only about 10 miles or so, but it might as well have been the moon.
One of the places they went is now called Huaricanga.
They built a mound here about 5,000 years ago.
Haas' team is now excavating it.
I'm Winifred Creamer.
I'm a professor at Northern Illinois University.
And today, what we're going to do is clear a profile.
The profile is a 10-foot high wall of dirt and rock created when farmers dug an irrigation ditch through the mound.
After people built the mounds, they sometimes lived on it.
This ditch is a lucky find; it exposed the mound from top to bottom like a layer cake.
But working conditions aren't good.
We reported on a potential partnership between Cal Poly, San Luis Obispo, and a Saudi Arabian university.
The proposed engineering program could be lucrative for the California university, but it comes with a string attached.
The Saudi university doesn't allow women in its engineering courses.

Dean Johnson(ph) of Ventura, California writes, I was stunned to hear that the university that is working with a Saudi Arabian university to arrange remote technical classes that exclude women was my own alma mater.
I love Cal Poly, but I will never forgive them for this if they proceed with this half-baked plan.
I imagine there are some positives and I'm all for bridge-building, but this is a step back in time to Cal Poly's early days educating male veterans after World War II.
On Friday, we reported on a proposal to have teenage British subjects swear allegiance to the queen.
Ellen Banks(ph) was stunned by what some Brits in the story had to say.
They said this would make them more like Americans, she writes.
There's a big difference between allegiance to the idea of a republic with liberty and justice for all and allegiance to an archaic hereditary monarchy.
Also, on Friday, we played this tape from the president's appearance at Washington's Gridiron Club dinner.
(Soundbite of President Bush singing)
President GEORGE W.
BUSH: (Singing) Yes, you're all gonna miss me, the way you used to diss me.
(Soundbite of laughter)
(Singing) But soon I'll touch the brown, brown grass of home.
Well, some of you were not amused.
This is from Anna Harris(ph) of Chicago.
It's great that NPR and other powerful media moguls are able to laugh about Bush's Gridiron performance, Ms. Harris writes.
That White House press secretary, Dana Perino says that this is one leak to media the president doesn't mind speaks volumes to this administration's and the media's cluelessness.
Kudos, NPR, for taking the bait.
If you have a comment, go to our Web site, npr.org, and click Contact Us at the top of the page.
Please don't forget to tell us where you're from and how to say your name.
Pittsburgh Steelers fans are mourning the death of one of their legends.
Myron Cope, with his trademark squeaky voice, spent 35 seasons as the team's radio announcer.
Not ""Hee Haw,"" that's the locker room show for tonight.
I'm Myron Cope.
Myron Cope died earlier this week at the age of 79.
Steelers fans adored his distinctive phrases often referred to as Cope-isms.
His outburst at a good play was often yoi, or that was a double yoi.
But perhaps his greatest contribution to sports was the Steelers' trademark Terrible Towel.
Steelers Hall of Fame wide receiver Lynn Swann won four NFL championships with the Steelers in the '70s when Myron Cope was on the air.
Lynn Swann joins me now.
Welcome to the show.
Jacki, thank you for inviting me on.
Many people who knew Myron Cope around the country are sad on this loss and what it means to his family, and certainly what it means to the Steeler nation, if you will.
Well, we certainly want to extend our condolences to you and to all the fans.
Let's describe one of the phenomena for which he was known and that is the Terrible Towel.
What is this, for people who haven't seen a Steelers Game?
Well, back in the mid-'70s, we were getting in the play-offs on a frequent basis and the radio station wanted to have something that would encourage the fans.
And Myron came up, apparently, with the idea of a towel and he named it the Terrible Towel.
And going into one of the play-off games, Myron put that towel on the stool and the bench of every player in the locker room.
And apparently a sponsor had put them on every seat in the stadium.
And as we were being introduced for this play-off game, I happened to have a towel in my hand and just nervous energy, I was kind of holding the towel and kind of just banging it against my leg.
And as I was being introduced, I started waving it in the air.

And then suddenly Myron went on the air talking about the fans waving the Terrible Towel, and the magic behind the fans powered to enthuse the Pittsburgh Steelers, and from that moment on, it's always been a staple of the Pittsburgh Steelers.
I understand that people have taken them home, draped their television sets, wrapped them around babies at baptisms and introduced them at weddings and funerals as well, right?
Absolutely.
It's just, you know, they take the Terrible Towel with them.
Some have had a single Terrible Towel, from the day they purchased it, for several years, and they think that is the one that they always have to take to the game or to take with them.

And indeed, when I came in from the airport -I was in Austin, Texas this week when Myron passed away and came back to Pittsburgh - there was a woman who sits there and she collects for the Salvation Army.
She had a picture of Myron Cope above the kettle and the kettle was draped in a Terrible Towel in remembrance of Myron.
Let me ask about that style he had of announcing.
Let's hear a little bit of that.
(Soundbite of Announcing)
Carter the strong safety, has got to be saying to himself, now how does that 250-pound back make a (unintelligible) out of me, put the move on me like he's Nijinsky?
Unidentified Man #1: Who was that again?
Nijinsky.
Unidentified Man #2: Nijinsky was a great ballet artist.
Unidentified Man #1: Now, why wouldn't you use Baryshnikov instead of Nijinsky?
Don't quibble with me, Oakland(ph).
Now, he sounds like a crow cawing, but he also had a lot of colorful descriptions.
I mean, he called your opposition the Cleveland Bunglers or the Baltimore Birdbrains.
All right.
Randy, thanks for the call.
It looks like there's not going to be a full FBI investigation.
The Department of Justice has issued a statement basically saying they view their job complete of vetting Brett Kavanaugh.
This is still better for Democrats, though, than the initial Republican plan to address this through committee phone calls with Kavanaugh and Ford.
Democrats had said they would boycott that process.
So could the delay actually derail this nomination altogether?
It's hard to say at this point.
But, you know, given the accusations and how serious they are, it's going to likely be a straight party-line vote at this point.
Republicans only have 51 votes.
Two Republicans voting no would sink Kavanaugh's nomination.
Jeff Flake said this evening that if you believe the charges are true, then you vote no. So this hearing's really going to be critical.
It's clear at this point Republicans are not going to get Kavanaugh on the bench before the start of the fall term.
And this is just a striking turn of events.
After that initial hearing a couple of weeks ago, Kavanaugh looked like he'd be a shoo-in.
And now things are really up in the air.
That's NPR's Scott Detrow.
Thanks for your reporting.
Thank you.
Here in Los Angeles, sports fans are eagerly awaiting the regular season debut of LeBron James.
He is now a member of the Los Angeles Lakers.
And he made a courtside appearance with his new team over the weekend.
(CHEERING)
All right.
While there are some LeBron haters here in LA, a lot of fans love LeBron the basketball player, but it is not clear how friendly the city of Los Angeles is going to be to LeBron the bicyclist.
Yeah.
Back in 2012, Yahoo published a picture of LeBron biking to a home game, and that was when he played for the Miami Heat.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
It was good to get out in the open field this morning, get a good bike ride and then be prepared for today's game.
You should take the bike every day.
